title: The Deadliest Routes: Mapping the Journey
text:
“Even though I went to university for five years, finding work outside my family business was difficult. We were battling one of the worst food crises in the world, struggling to even be able to pay for flour or a pack of spaghetti.  I felt suffocated and discouraged in Venezuela…”
- Alisa Domingo
The decision to migrate is never made lightly. For families like Alisa’s, it often comes after exhausting all other options. The root causes of migration in the Americas are complex and interconnected, ranging from economic collapse to political instability and climate-related disasters (International Organization for Migration (IOM) 2024).
Alisa’s story begins in Venezuela, where economic collapse left her family with nothing (Domingo and Loeza 2025). She immigrated to Peru where she worked multiple jobs and continued to struggle to survive. Finally, she made the difficult decision to leave everything behind and seek a better life in the United States. The journey north is fraught with danger at every step. From the treacherous Darién Gap to the scorching deserts of the US-Mexico border, migrants face life-threatening challenges in their search for safety and opportunity.

title: The Deadliest Routes: Mapping the Journey
text:
Personal Stories: Beyond the Numbers

Alisa’s Story
After a long and difficult journey, Alisa found hope in the U.S., building a new life with her partner, Alex, and preparing for the birth of their daughter. Tragedy struck when Alex was killed, leaving Alisa to face motherhood alone. Despite immense loss and ongoing uncertainty about her immigration status, Alisa’s resilience endures. Her story is a powerful reminder that behind every migration statistic is a human life, full of hope and courage.

title: The Human Cost of Migration in the Americas
text:
Mother and child
Arifur Rahman on Unsplash
Alisa’s words cut through the noise and stereotypes surrounding migration (Domingo and Loeza 2025). Her story is one of thousands-people who leave everything behind seeking safety and a better future for their families. Yet, despite their hopes, these journeys are fraught with danger.
In January 2024 alone, over 250 migrants died or went missing across the Americas-the deadliest month on record (International Organization for Migration (IOM) 2024). These numbers are not just statistics; they represent mothers, fathers, children, and individuals like Alisa, whose lives hang in the balance or have been tragically lost. Understanding this human cost is essential to grasping the scale and urgency of the migration crisis today.

title: The Human Cost of Migration in the Americas
text:
Regions and Incidents



Figure 1: Each point represents an incident where migrants were reported missing or deceased. The size of the circle indicates the density of casualties. Click on points for detailed information.

Temporal patterns: Incidents of migrants casualties by region
While the map highlights where these tragic incidents occur, it’s also important to understand how the scale of the crisis has changed over time. The following chart illustrates trends in reported deaths and disappearances across different regions of the Americas, revealing how risks have evolved in recent years.
North America consistently accounts for the highest number of cases, with notable increases in recent years. Central America, the Caribbean, and South America also show persistent and, at times, rising numbers, reflecting the widespread risks faced by migrants throughout the region. This trend highlights the ongoing and growing dangers associated with migration routes across the Americas.

Figure 2: The data reveals a concerning upward trend in migrant deaths and disappearances over the past decade. Each number represents a life lost, a family shattered, and a community forever changed.
To better capture recent developments and short-term fluctuations, the next chart breaks down these incidents by month. This view reveals not only long-term trends but also seasonal patterns and sudden spikes in migrant deaths and disappearances across the Americas. The recent spike in January 2024 represents the deadliest month on record, with over 250 lives lost.

Figure 3: The interactive graph above shows the monthly toll of migrant deaths and disappearances. Use your mouse to hover over the points to see the exact number of deaths and disappearances for each month. The red line represents the raw data, while the blue line shows the smoothed trend.






Key Findings




The US-Mexico border remains the deadliest crossing, accounting for 75% of all incidents.
The Darién Gap between Colombia and Panama (the land bridge between Central and South America) has seen a surge in deaths, becoming the third most dangerous route.
Despite increased awareness, the number of deaths continues to rise.





Factors Driving the Increase
Several interconnected factors contribute to the rising death toll:

Policy Changes: Stricter border policies often push migrants toward more dangerous routes
Climate Impact: Extreme weather events make crossings more hazardous
Economic Pressures: Growing economic disparities drive more people to attempt dangerous journeys
Political Instability: Unrest in various countries forces more people to flee

title: About
text:
The Human Cost of Migration in the Americas is a data-driven storytelling project that reveals the urgent realities faced by migrants across the Americas. Blending data analysis with the deeply personal journey of Alisa Domingo, this project brings to light the human stories behind the statistics of missing and deceased migrants.
Through interactive maps, visualizations, and Alisa Domingo’s personal story, this project reveals the scale and dangers of migration routes across the Americas. It explores why migrants risk these journeys, the legal barriers they face, and calls for urgent action to protect their dignity and lives.
This project was completed as part of MUSA 6951: Communication in Urban Spatial Analytics at the University of Pennsylvania, under the guidance of Dr. Elizabeth Delmelle.

Special thanks to all migrants and communities whose stories bring vital human context to this critical issue.

title: Responses & Conclusion
text:
“We are not criminals. We are human beings seeking safety and opportunity. We deserve dignity and respect.”
- Alisa Domingo

As we reflect on the data presented in this project, we must remember that behind every statistic is a person like Alisa. Her journey from Venezuela through the treacherous Darién Gap to the US-Mexico border represents the experiences of thousands who undertake this perilous path each year.
The numbers tell a sobering story:

Total Since 2014: 9,791 lives lost or missing 2024 (Year to Date): 830 casualties Yearly Average: 816 casualties per year


Most Dangerous Route: US-Mexico Border (75% of all incidents)
Deadliest Month: January 2024 (250+ casualties)



Yet, these numbers cannot fully capture the human cost. They cannot convey the fear Alisa felt as she walked through the jungle, “feeling the blood of those who came before on her feet.” They cannot express the pain of losing her partner Alex to gun violence, or the terror she felt when her daughter Ana’s heart stopped beating for five minutes during birth. They cannot show the strength it takes to raise a child alone while facing an uncertain immigration status.


Alisa’s story also reveals the complex and often arbitrary nature of the US immigration system. After surviving the dangerous journey through the Darién Gap and Mexico, she faced new challenges:

The CBP One App: Like many migrants, Alisa had to navigate the CBP One app system, calling the US consulate daily for updates while waiting in Mexico City
Missed Deadlines: Due to the trauma of losing her partner Alex and the complications of her pregnancy, she missed the deadline to apply for asylum
Changing Policies: The termination of protections for Venezuelan citizens left her in legal limbo
Birthright Citizenship Concerns: The threat to birthright citizenship puts her US-born daughter Ana at risk

These bureaucratic hurdles highlight how even those who follow legal pathways can find themselves trapped in uncertainty, their futures dependent on shifting political winds rather than their contributions to society.



The solutions to this crisis are complex, but they begin with recognizing our shared humanity. We must:

Expand Legal Pathways: Create more opportunities for safe, legal migration
Invest in Root Causes: Address economic instability, climate change, and political unrest
Strengthen Humanitarian Response: Increase funding and coordination for search and rescue operations
Protect Human Rights: Ensure that all migrants are treated with dignity and respect

The time to act is now. Together, we can create a future where no one has to risk her life in search of safety and opportunity. Where families can stay together, regardless of immigration status. Where every person’s right to dignity and respect is recognized, and where the words “I am not a criminal, I am only a mother” are met with compassion rather than fear.

title: The Human Cost of Migration in the Americas
text:
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE)
if (interactive()) {
  options(device = function() {
    quartz()
  })
}
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)
library(ggtext)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(sf)
library(tidyr)
library(rnaturalearth)
library(geosphere)
library(ggtext)
library(plotly)
library(leaflet)
library(htmlwidgets)


# Load and process data
all_data <- read_csv("./data/Missing_Migrants_Global_Figures_allData.csv")

americas_data <- all_data %>%
  separate(Coordinates, into = c("Latitude", "Longitude"), sep = ", ", convert = TRUE) %>%
  filter(!is.na(Latitude) & !is.na(Longitude)) %>%
  filter(`Region of Incident` %in% c("North America", "South America", "Central America", "Caribbean"))

# Define geographical bounds
lat_min <- -60   # Southernmost point in South America
lat_max <- 50    # Northernmost point in North America
lon_min <- -130  # Westernmost point in North America
lon_max <- -30   # Easternmost point in South America

americas_data <- americas_data %>%
  filter(Latitude >= lat_min & Latitude <= lat_max & 
         Longitude >= lon_min & Longitude <= lon_max)

# Prepare map data
countries <- ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf") %>%
  select(name, continent, geometry)

focus_regions <- c("North America", "South America", "Central America", "Caribbean")
focus_countries <- countries %>%
  filter(continent %in% focus_regions)

americas_sf <- st_as_sf(americas_data, coords = c("Longitude", "Latitude"), crs = 4326)
focus_countries <- st_transform(focus_countries, 4326)
combined_data <- st_join(americas_sf, focus_countries)


# Create summary statistics
casualty_summary <- americas_data %>%
  mutate(Year = year(`Incident Date`)) %>%
  group_by(Year) %>%
  summarise(Total_Casualties = sum(`Total Number of Dead and Missing`, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ungroup()

# Calculate total since 2014
total_since_2014 <- sum(casualty_summary$Total_Casualties)

# Get 2024 data
casualties_2024 <- casualty_summary %>%
  filter(Year == 2024) %>%
  pull(Total_Casualties)

# Calculate yearly average
yearly_avg <- mean(casualty_summary$Total_Casualties)

# Create regional breakdown
regional_summary <- americas_data %>%
  mutate(Year = year(`Incident Date`)) %>%
  group_by(`Region of Incident`) %>%
  summarise(
    Total_Casualties = sum(`Total Number of Dead and Missing`, na.rm = TRUE),
    Percentage = round(Total_Casualties / total_since_2014 * 100, 1)
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(Total_Casualties))

# Create summary tables
summary_table <- data.frame(
  Time_Period = c("Total Since 2014", "2024 (Year to Date)", "Yearly Average"),
  Casualties = c(total_since_2014, casualties_2024, round(yearly_avg, 0))
)

# Format the main summary table
kable(summary_table, 
      col.names = c("Time Period", "Total Casualties"),
      caption = "Summary of Migrant Casualties in the Americas",
      format = "html") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"),
                full_width = FALSE,
                position = "left") %>%
  column_spec(2, bold = TRUE)

# Format the regional breakdown table
kable(regional_summary, 
      col.names = c("Region", "Total Casualties", "Percentage"),
      caption = "Regional Breakdown of Casualties Since 2014",
      format = "html") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"),
                full_width = FALSE,
                position = "left") %>%
  column_spec(2:3, bold = TRUE)

# Create a bar chart of regional breakdown
regional_plot <- ggplot(regional_summary, aes(x = reorder(`Region of Incident`, -Total_Casualties), 
                                             y = Total_Casualties,
                                             fill = `Region of Incident`)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(Percentage, "%")), 
            vjust = -0.5, 
            size = 4) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("North America" = "#E41A1C",
                              "Central America" = "#377EB8",
                              "Caribbean" = "#4DAF4A",
                              "South America" = "#984EA3")) +
  labs(
    title = "Regional Distribution of Migrant Casualties",
    x = "Region",
    y = "Total Casualties",
    caption = "Data Source: Missing Migrants Project"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    legend.position = "none"
  )

# print(regional_plot)  # Commented out to prevent output


# Create an interactive map using leaflet
leaflet_map <- leaflet(combined_data) %>%
  addTiles() %>%
  setView(lng = -80, lat = 03, zoom = 2.75) %>%
  addCircleMarkers(
    radius = ~sqrt(`Total Number of Dead and Missing`) * 3,
    color = ~case_when(
      `Region of Incident` == "North America" ~ "#E41A1C",
      `Region of Incident` == "Central America" ~ "#377EB8",
      `Region of Incident` == "Caribbean" ~ "#4DAF4A",
      `Region of Incident` == "South America" ~ "#984EA3"
    ),
    popup = ~paste(
      "<strong>Region:</strong>", `Region of Incident`,
      "<br><strong>Date:</strong>", `Incident Date`,
      "<br><strong>Dead/Missing:</strong>", `Total Number of Dead and Missing`,
      "<br><strong>Route:</strong>", `Migration Route`
    ),
    fillOpacity = 0.7
  ) %>%
  addLegend(
    position = "bottomright",
    colors = c("#E41A1C", "#377EB8", "#4DAF4A", "#984EA3"),
    labels = c("North America", "Central America", "Caribbean", "South America"),
    title = "Region of Incident"
  )

# Commented out to prevent output
# saveWidget(leaflet_map, "map.html", selfcontained = TRUE)
# leaflet_map


yearly_region_data <- americas_data %>%
  mutate(Year = year(`Incident Date`)) %>%
  group_by(Year, `Region of Incident`) %>%
  summarise(Total = sum(`Total Number of Dead and Missing`, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = 'drop')

# Reorder based on totals
region_totals <- yearly_region_data %>%
  group_by(`Region of Incident`) %>%
  summarise(Total = sum(Total)) %>%
  arrange(desc(Total))

yearly_region_data$`Region of Incident` <- factor(yearly_region_data$`Region of Incident`, 
                                                  levels = region_totals$`Region of Incident`)


my_plot <- ggplot(yearly_region_data, aes(x = Year, y = Total, fill = `Region of Incident`)) +
  geom_area(alpha = 0.8, color = "white") +
  annotate(
    geom = "richtext", x = 2015, y = 1300, 
    label = "Followed by <br> **<span style='color:#377EB8;'>Central America</span>**, <br> the **<span style='color:#4DAF4A;'>Caribbean</span>**, and <br> **<span style='color:#984EA3;'>South America</span>**.",
    hjust = 0, vjust = 1, size = 4, color = "#333333", 
    fill = NA, label.color = NA
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Caribbean" = "#4DAF4A", 
                              "Central America" = "#377EB8", 
                              "North America" = "#E41A1C", 
                              "South America" = "#984EA3")) +
  labs(
    title = "**<span style='color:#E41A1C;'>North America</span>** has the most incidents<br>of missing or dead migrants over time.",
    x = NULL,
    y = NULL,
    caption = "Data Source: Missing Migrants Project"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_family = "Helvetica", base_size = 15) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_markdown(hjust=0, color = "#333333"),
    plot.caption = element_text(size=10, hjust=0),
    legend.position = "none"
  )

# Commented out to prevent output
# ggsave("yearly_region_plot.png", my_plot, width = 8, height = 5, dpi = 300)
# print(my_plot)


# Interactive Journey Map: typical migration path from Venezuela to the United States.
# Create journey data
journey_data <- data.frame(
  stage = c("Origin", "First Border", "Darién Gap", "Central America", "Mexico", "US Border"),
  risk_level = c(1, 2, 5, 3, 4, 5),
  lat = c(10.5, 8.0, 8.5, 15.0, 19.0, 29.0),
  lon = c(-66.9, -74.0, -77.5, -90.0, -99.0, -98.0),
  description = c(
    "Venezuela: Economic crisis forces families to leave",
    "Colombia: Preparing for the dangerous jungle crossing",
    "Panama: The deadly Darién Gap crossing begins",
    "Guatemala: Navigating multiple borders",
    "Mexico: The long journey north",
    "Texas: The final, often fatal, crossing"
  )
)

# Generate great circle paths between points
journey_points <- journey_data[, c("lon", "lat")]
gc_paths <- lapply(1:(nrow(journey_points)-1), function(i) {
  gcIntermediate(
    journey_points[i,],
    journey_points[i+1,],
    n = 50,
    addStartEnd = TRUE,
    sp = FALSE
  )
})

# Create interactive journey map
journey_map <- leaflet(journey_data) %>%
  addTiles() %>%
  addCircleMarkers(
    ~lon, ~lat,
    radius = ~risk_level * 5,
    color = ~colorRampPalette(c("#4DAF4A", "#E41A1C"))(6)[risk_level],
    popup = ~paste(
      "<strong>", stage, "</strong><br>",
      description, "<br>",
      "Risk Level: ", risk_level, "/5"
    ),
    opacity = 0.8
  )

# Add each great circle segment
for (path in gc_paths) {
  journey_map <- journey_map %>%
    addPolylines(
      lng = path[,1],
      lat = path[,2],
      color = "#666666",
      weight = 2,
      opacity = 0.6
    )
}

# Commented out to prevent output
# saveWidget(journey_map, "journey_map.html", selfcontained = TRUE)
# print(journey_map)


# Create monthly data
monthly_data <- americas_data %>%
  mutate(Month = floor_date(`Incident Date`, "month")) %>%
  group_by(Month) %>%
  summarise(Total = sum(`Total Number of Dead and Missing`, na.rm = TRUE))

# Create interactive time series plot
p <- ggplot(monthly_data, aes(x = Month, y = Total)) +
  geom_line(color = "#E41A1C") +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, color = "#377EB8") +
  labs(
    title = "Monthly Migrant Deaths and Disappearances",
    x = "Date",
    y = "Number of Dead and Missing",
    caption = "Data: Missing Migrants Project"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10)
  )
